awd_abstract_narration:
Employment in the biotechnology industry offers good benefits, job satisfaction, and opportunities for advancement. Despite these advantages, the lack of knowledge on the part of students and teachers concerning biotech careers has made it difficult to recruit students to enroll in biotech education programs. This project will add features and services to the website, Biotech-Careers.org, which currently serves to inform students about the types of job opportunities in biotech, to identify where biotechnology students have been hired, and to help biotech education programs learn what companies are doing in their local areas. The site contains descriptions of careers in biotech companies, stories and photos from graduates of two-year programs, and a database of biotech-related employers tagged by their business area. Additions to the site will enable it to improve student awareness of the different types of job opportunities in biotechnology and help them learn where they can find college programs that can prepare them for these different types of biotech careers. To complement these services, the project team will also identify and recruit faculty who are committed to being part of a distributed national leadership council to promote improvements in biotechnology education.
 
The project will pursue two primary objectives. First, the project team will introduce capabilities to Biotech-Careers.org that help improve students? knowledge of opportunities in biotech and ability to find employment. Second, the principal investigators will improve and sustain the digital infrastructure connecting the biotech-education online community. Through these efforts, students will be provided with new tools for identifying and planning their career objectives and locating educational programs that can prepare them for biotech careers. These resources will include better descriptions of career pathways, better links to community college biotech programs, more information about where students are getting hired, and new tools designed to help students overcome barriers when applying for jobs. The directory and database of community college and high school biotech programs at a companion site, Bio-Link.org, will also be improved and will continue to serve as a tool for assessing biotech education on a national level. The broader impacts of this project will be to increase the number and diversity of appropriately educated students entering biotechnology and bioscience careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals for this project were to 1) sustain the Bio-Link community, a network of faculty, two-year college biotechnology programs, and high schools that taught biotechnology and 2) preserve two Bio-Link resources: Bio-Link.org, a website with a database of biotechnology college programs and Biotech-Careers.org, a website with information about entry-level biotechnology careers. Additional goals were to add features and improvements to Biotech-Careers.org and make the site sustainable.

 

During this project, our team successfully transitioned the Bio-Link community to InnovATEBIO, an NSF-funded Advanced Technological Education Center for Biotechnology.  The Bio-Link.org educational database was preserved, updated to InnovATEBIO.org, and continues to grow. Once this goal had been accomplished, our efforts focused largely on adding features and improvements to Biotech-Careers.org. 

 

 

In order to make Biotech-Careers.org sustainable, we added a job board and options for advertising. These activities have supported web hosting for the past few years.

 

Biotech-Careers' mission is to provide a comprehensive resource where visitors can learn about biotechnology careers.  We have given many presentations to students and often describe site resources as:  people, places, products, pathways, and jobs. The site seeks to answer students questions about careers that align with their interests and describe what the jobs are, what people do in those jobs, the skills that are required, and where they can learn those skills.

  

To study places, interactive maps and a database with over 9000 companies, and over 530 business areas, allow visitors to see where companies are located and what they do. Site visitors can filter information by product, country, state, city, and whether or not a company advertises for employees on their website. A word map of products supplies a visual image of the number of companies working on different technologies. Visitors can use these links to find companies working in different areas such as "Cancer treatments" or "Women's health."

 

 

Students are often interested in knowing something about the people who work in biotechnology. Profiles of community college alumni help them learn about the people in biotech and the pathways they followed as part of their careers. 

 

36 careers are described at Biotech-Careers.org.  Each career page includes an average salary, education requirements and the skills that are commonly associated with those careers.  The skills are linked to descriptions and tools for searching the job board to see companies looking for those skills. Links to community colleges help site visitors learn where they can learn those skills. At least 10% of the people who visit InnovATEBIO come from Biotech-Careers.org. 

The career resources and information at Biotech-Careers.org have made it one of the most widely used websites to be developed by an NSF-funded project.  The site received over 630,000 unique visits in the last 12 months.  Our data from past analyses show at least a quarter of those visits come from schools. 


We gave several virtual presentations on Biotech-Careers.org to high school and college students during the course of the project.  We found that using the site raised awareness of biotechnology careers. Students also reported that using the site broadened their ideas about who can be successful in biotechnology, helped them picture themselves in a biotechnology career and increased the likelihood that they would pursue a career in biotechnology.


We have also worked to create an educational resource that leverages Biotech-Careers.org to go beyond a web-based experience.  This resource, Biotechopoly: Antibody Edition, helps players learn about careers in biotechnology through game play. Teams of players work to bring drugs to market by moving their products through the stages of drug development. They purchase data and documents to move from pre-clinical research to phase I, phase II/III, and finally to market. Whoever gets to market first, wins.


Similar to Monopoly, teams move their companies along the outside of the board. During this process, they hire people for different roles, purchase data and documents, and raise funds.  They also encounter luck and karma along the way.  Luck can be good or bad.  Karma is usually bad but a company can protect itself from bad karma by hiring the right people.  All the luck and karma stories come from real life.  QR codes on the luck cards allow players to learn about the stories that inspired the cards. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 07/25/2024
Modified by: Sandra G Porter

    Sandra Porter, Digital World Biology

    Effects of using Biotech-Careers.org
  • Biotech-Careers.org has both icons and menu titles to promote navigation. Visitors can easily see where companies are located, learn about people working in biotech, the topics companies work on, and learn about careers.
    Digital World Biology
    Copyrighted
    Sandra G Porter
    Biotech-Careers.org home page
  • This is an alumni profile page. He talks about his career journey in the video. The information on the page describes his career path, where he went to college, and his degree.
    Digital World Biology
    Copyrighted
    Sandra G Porter
    A Laboratory Associate
  • This is a career page at Biotech-Careers.org. Fast Facts and skills show the salary and education needed for this position. Skills needed are categorized as knowledge, technical, and professional. The orange button searches for jobs. Details about the work and other requirements are below.
    Digital World Biology
    Copyrighted
    Sandra G Porter
    Upstream Biomanufacturing Technician
  • Biotechnology is a worldwide business. The company database contains entries from all over world with links to company websites and descriptions of company activities and whether they've hired community college graduates.
    Digital World Biology
    Copyrighted
    Sandra G Porter
    Biotechnology company database

Once this goal had been accomplished, our efforts focused largely on adding features and improvements to Biotech-Careers.org.





 


In order to make Biotech-Careers.org sustainable, we added a job board and options for advertising. These activities have supported web hosting for the past few years.
